stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the whole session rough-planning the RTYI overworld.  Using Photoshop he sketches a multi-area version of Yoshi’s Island, discusses course entrances, star/puzzle locks, quick-warp pipes, terrain themes and visual landmarks.  The work is purely conceptual; no in-game editing occurs.

development_findings.summary: Overworld will represent the entirety of Yoshi’s Island, split into ~14 smaller areas (each its own level) and overall about four times the size of Mario 64’s castle grounds.
development_findings.quote: I’m thinking the overworld will be around four times the size of Super Mario 64. We have a lot more side levels so I think it makes sense.

development_findings.summary: Design philosophy: any place the player can see must eventually be reachable, and fast-travel pipes will connect distant points once corks are removed.
development_findings.quote: For the overworld it’s very important to me that if you can see it as a player then you can go there…  we’ll have pipes around the overworld everywhere with a cork you pull from one side.

development_findings.summary: Part 1 (starter beach-side cliff) contains Course 1 entrance, a river, a lighthouse landmark and cliffs that constrain exploration until later jumps are learned.
Course 2 will sit behind a cave at the end of the same river; a door or rapids will require stars or a powered boat to enter, forcing players to clear Course 1 first.
development_findings.quote: Inside the island there’s a river with a strong current—you need something to make it past the rapids … that’s a certified banger idea.

development_findings.summary: Course 3 is being moved to a later overworld zone to avoid overwhelming new players with three open courses at once.
Star-gating is still being prototyped; ideas include Bowser/Kamek magical barriers, miners needing ‘power of 5 stars’ to clear rocks, and visible star counters similar to Mario 64 doors.
development_findings.quote: Half the advantage of having a barrier that says you need 10 stars is that when you’re at 8 you know you just need two more.

development_findings.summary: Ghost Ship entrance concept: ship initially obscured by fog; player enters lighthouse, activates a switch that turns the beam onto the bay, dispels fog and solidifies the ship so it can be boarded.
development_findings.quote: What if the ship is here but it’s like a shadowy fig … in the lighthouse you point the light at the ship and that makes the ship visible and breaks through the fog.

development_findings.summary: Zoo (Course 4/5) gate: Wario stands at wooden gate demanding 9,999 coins; Kaze prefers a secret workaround (breaking gate with a boulder, luring a Chain Chomp, or solving an ice-cap puzzle).  Final mechanic undecided.
Quick-warp design: after traversing the jungle (Part 2) and reaching Part 3, a two-way pipe opens so future visits skip the intermediate ‘edging’ section.
development_findings.quote: Some overworld parts will be anticipatory … after the edging is done having the quick warp from Part 1 to Part 3 is perfect.

development_findings.summary: Planned landmarks & themes: jungle clearing with Yoshi village around a lake, broken castles from Yoshi’s Island endings, Super Happy Tree, waterfalls & rapids, under-island cave system, possible volcano & cloud areas.
Kaze will create a 2-D map and a grey-box 3-D sketch, then beta-test exploration before committing to art and collision.
development_findings.quote: Because the overworld is so important we’re going to plan it, make a 2-D sketch, then a 3-D sketch with all the double entrances drawn in and beta-test just the sketch so we can still adjust it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze streams while sick and forgets his own wedding anniversary until Zeina reminds him on stream.
context_findings.quote: It’s our wedding anniversary. – Oh, I forgot. – It’s okay, I forgot too.

context_findings.summary: He expresses frustration with Nvidia Broadcast and broken FPS counters at stream start.
Personal philosophy: reluctant to solicit outside help because rejecting sub-par contributions feels bad.
context_findings.quote: If I ask someone for a favor I can’t just say actually you did a bad job—that always feels super bad for everyone involved.

biobak.summary: Confirms overworld size feels right and discusses shoe-horning levels like Mario 64 did.

badub.summary: Expected to compose the full soundtrack; Kaze plans to ask for a complete OST and possibly a Mario 64 medley but hasn’t approached him yet.

zeina.summary: Provides concept sketches for Mario’s traversal and Yoshi huts; briefly appears on stream; currently drawing retro ‘rainbow road’ boards.

key_stories.title: The Lighthouse Reveals the Ghost Ship
key_stories.summary: Initially the Ghost Ship is an intangible silhouette in fog.  Kaze invents a puzzle where the player restores an old lighthouse and its beam pierces the fog, materialising the ship entrance.
key_stories.challenge: Needed a memorable, in-universe way to gate Course 5 without another star door.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed obstacles (fog, anchors, heavy enemies) and finally settled on an interactive lighthouse with a cut-scene spotlight.
key_stories.outcome: Concept accepted as the official path to the Ghost Ship; to be implemented later.
key_stories.key_quote: What if the ship is here but it’s a shadowy fig, and you go into the lighthouse and point the light at it, and that makes the ship visible and breaks through the fog.

key_stories.title: Designing the River-Cave for Course 2
key_stories.summary: Courses 1 & 2 both sit off the starter beach.  Kaze realises players must not reach Course 2 too early, so he threads the island’s main river through a cave with a star-locked door or current.
key_stories.challenge: Prevent players from skipping ahead while keeping the world feeling cohesive.
key_stories.process: Proposed strong current, powered boat, or star door inside a cave entered from the river mouth.
key_stories.outcome: River-cave concept adopted; star/puzzle specifics to follow.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe you can’t swim up the river because of the strong current—you need something to make it past.

key_stories.title: Quick-Warp Pipes to Preserve Pacing
key_stories.summary: Traversing the jungle path (Part 2) is meant to build anticipation once, but would be tedious on repeats.
key_stories.challenge: Avoid back-tracking drudgery after the initial reveal.
key_stories.process: Plans a corked pipe linking Part 1 and Part 3 that unlocks as soon as Part 3 is reached.
key_stories.outcome: Pipe system becomes canonical for fast travel across the island.
key_stories.key_quote: After you go through Part 2 to Part 3 you can open this pipe and now you have a quick warp—so you don’t have to walk through Part 2 again.

open_questions.context: Multiple ideas (magical seals, miners, star-powered doors) were floated but no system chosen.
questions: Have you finalised a universal visual language for star requirements?
Will the text or NPCs indicate exact numbers like Mario 64’s doors?

open_questions.context: Concepts include paying Wario, breaking a wooden gate, luring Chain Chomp, or requiring Ice Cap; nothing settled.
questions: Which mechanism best fits the game’s tone and pacing?
How will the Chain Chomp (or alternative) technically work in the overworld?

open_questions.context: Kaze envisions a cut-scene that re-points the beam; concerns about giving players camera control to aim the light.
questions: Will the lighthouse be a player-controlled mechanic or a simple switch?
What N64 performance constraints exist for dynamic light beams and fog?
Who will script the cut-scene and shader work?

open_questions.context: Kaze joked about shaping the island like a Yoshi head but was unsure.
questions: Has the team agreed on the final landmass outline?
If yes, how will the silhouette influence gameplay landmarks?

open_questions.context: Badub is expected to compose, but Kaze hasn’t formally asked.
questions: Is Badub confirmed as sole composer for RTYI?
What musical direction (original vs. Mario 64 remixes) has the team decided?
